Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Modeling Social Interaction and Performance in STEM Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research on Education and Learning (REAL) project arises from an October 2014 Ideas Lab on Data-intensive Research to Improve Teaching and Learning. The intentions of that effort were to: (1) bring together researchers from across disciplines to foster novel, transformative, multidisciplinary approaches to using the data in large education-related data sets to create actionable knowledge for improving STEM teaching and learning environments in the medium term; and (2) revolutionize learning in the longer term. In this project, researchers from the Educational Testing Service, Columbia University Teachers' College, Arizona State University, and North Carolina State University will conduct data-driven, exploratory analyses to identify key places where social interactions impact learning outcomes in specific learning environments, with the goal of improving teaching and learning in large-scale STEM courses.

This research takes advantage of data traces left in large-scale blended and online learning environments (including massively open online courses, or MOOCs). The researchers will develop a comprehensive model for social learning in the context of such courses that will enable assessment of both the collaborative needs of individuals within the context of a class, and the quality of collaborations they are carrying out. Such diagnoses will allow both instructors and automated systems to provide advice to learners about the peers they might work with to enhance their learning (e.g., regarding the kinds of social interactions that will foster better understanding and development of important disciplinary capabilities). An interdisciplinary team of investigators with expertise in theory-driven educational data mining, natural-language processing, psychometrics, social-network analysis, and computer support for collaborative learning will collaborate to explore when learners in blended and online classes benefit from social interactions, and to understand how to identify more and less productive collaborative interactions. The researchers will use data from three blended and online classes (e.g., log files capturing collaborative discussions, individual and collaborative interactions around well-instrumented examples, peer tutoring sessions, pair programming labs, paired projects) and a variety of data analysis approaches (e.g., text analysis, machine learning) to determine: (1) which cognitive, social, and affective dimensions of need and interaction can be identified from available data; (2) which analyses are useful in providing action-oriented collaboration advice; and (3) what additional types of data may be needed for making such recommendations. This exploration will be grounded in theories of social interactions for learning (e.g., self-explanation, dialectic with oneself and others, zone of proximal development, social learning theory of Bandura, peripheral and centripetal participation).

POR.DRECONTENT:
An increasing amount of student work is conducted on computers and online, producing vast amounts of learning-related and social interaction data. Despite long-standing awareness that social interaction is an integral part of knowledge construction, efforts to study the role of social interactions in learning have traditionally been limited to mono-disciplinary and small-scale studies. Data available through online learning environments, including massive open online courses (MOOCs), open doors to the potential for scaling up such analyses and to addressing novel questions. 

This collaborative research project leveraged the expertise of an interdisciplinary research team from psychology, linguistics, computer science, and data sciences with specializations in natural language processing, discourse analysis, social network analysis, educational data mining and psychometrics. The project goals were to examine relations between social interactions within online classes and to leverage student interactions within these environments to predict and potentially enhance learning. Across multiple studies, this work combined data streams from multiple sources of online course data to successfully model social interactions among learners and to reveal important relations between social interactions, language, and academic performance. 

This project was impactful at multiple levels. First, it offered multiple opportunities for the training and professional development of students and postdoctoral mentees. Student and postdoctoral mentee colaboaratively participated in tool development, data analyses, and publication of findings.  As such, they experienced a broad range of activities related to conducting educational research, preparing them for successful STEM careers. In addition the project outcomes directly impact multiple domains including educational data mining, the use of artificial intelligence in education, natural language processing, and education, with particularly strong contributions to theories of social learning and collaboration. One particular contribution of this project is creation of hybrid models informed by qualitative and quantitative methods at multiple grain sizes to assess the complex social nature of learning. The transformative potential of this research resides in the creation of new cross-disciplinary approaches that can be used to improve teaching and learning in STEM, by leveraging social interaction and collaboration data alongside disciplinary artifacts and assessment outcomes. In addition, one objective of this project has been to provide researchers with access to online tools that afford greater access to natural language processing.  To this end, several tools have been developed and open access is provided on soletlab.com (see tools).  

The broader impacts of this project address a core question of shifting education to a data-rich activity. The outputs of this research are models that can be used to assess social interaction quality alongside cognitive measures and the explicit interaction between these factors in STEM learning. Such output measures can be used by educators to design experiences and incentivize behaviors, which in turn maximize the social learning benefit, leading to improved STEM performance and retention. As such, online learning environments can be built to automatically recommend behaviors suited to student, group, and class needs.
